chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect coronavirus infection?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• COVID-19 has a predilection for the upper and lower respiratory tract alveolar cells and is spread by droplets from sneezing and coughing.
  • The prodrome (pre-illness phase) lasts between 2–10 days. 
  • The commonest symptoms are fever, a new and continuous cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, loss of appetite, anosmia (loss of smell) and ageusia (loss of taste).
  • Other symptoms include headache, muscle pain, sore throat, nasal congestion, chest pain, nausea and vomiting, diarrhoea, skin rashes (especially in younger people). 
    • Delirium and reduced mobility can appear in the elderly and immunocompromised people, often in the absence of fever.
  • A study in Spain reported the following patterns of skin rashes:
    • Maculopapular eruptions (47%).
    • Acral areas of erythema with vesicles or pustules (so called ‘pseudo‐chilblains’) (19%) – this frequently appears later in the disease (59% after other symptoms). 
    • Urticarial lesions (19%).
    • Other vesicular eruptions (9%) — vesicular eruptions appear early in the course of the disease (15% before other symptoms). 
    • Livedo or necrosis (6%). 
  • The illness is variable in severity from asymptomatic, to mild upper respiratory tract infection in some people to severe pneumonia in others.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This information is based on the Public Health England (PHE) document COVID-19: epidemiology, virology and clinical features [PHE, 2020c], a report of 72, 314 case series [Wu and McGoogan, 2020], a retrospective study [Chen et al, 2020], and a prospective consensus study [Galván Casas, 2020].

  • In a study of the first 99 patients diagnosed with COVID-19 in China, it was found that the majority of people had fever or cough (83%) and a third of patients had shortness of breath. Other symptoms included muscle ache, headache, confusion, chest pain, and vomiting and diarrhoea (3% and 5%). Many patients presented with organ function damage, including 17 (17%) with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), eight (8%) with acute respiratory injury, three (3%) with acute kidney injury, four (4%) with sepsis, and one (1%) with ventilator-associated pneumonia. 

[Wu and McGoogan, 2020; Chen et al, 2020]

  • A study in Spain of 375 people with COVID-19 reported the following patterns of cutaneous manifestations [Galván Casas, 2020]:
    • Maculopapular eruptions (47%).
    • Acral areas of erythema with vesicles or pustules (so called ‘pseudo‐chilblains’) (19%).
    • Urticarial lesions (19%).
    • Other vesicular eruptions (9%).
    • Livedo or necrosis (6%).
  • The authors noted that vesicular eruptions appear early in the course of the disease (15% before other symptoms) and the ‘pseudo‐chilblain’ pattern frequently appears later in the disease (59% after other symptoms), while the rest tend to appear with the other symptoms of COVID‐19.
